title: Advanced Techniques with ggsaveR
text: vignette covers advanced features ggsaveR, focusing reproducibility fine-grained control. explore embed reproducibility data PNG files use guard argument bypass global settings specific ggsave() calls.

title: Advanced Techniques with ggsaveR
text: maximum reproducibility, ggsaveR can embed ggplot object, R code generated , session information directly PNG file’s metadata. controlled ggsaveR.embed_data option. option TRUE, plot saved PNG contain extra information. ggsaveR captures plot-generating code, even using pipes. can use read_ggsaveR_data() function extract information saved PNG.
code: options(ggsaveR.embed_data = TRUE) # The plot object and the code below are embedded in the PNG file iris |>   subset(Species != "setosa") |>   ggplot(aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length)) +   geom_point(aes(color = Species)) |>   ggsave("plot_with_embedded_data.png") # Read the embedded data embedded_info <- read_ggsaveR_data("plot_with_embedded_data.png")  # View the code that generated the plot cat(embedded_info$plot_call) #> iris |> #>   subset(Species != "setosa") |> #>   ggplot(aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length)) + #>   geom_point(aes(color = Species))  # You can even replot the original ggplot object # embedded_info$plot_object # Reset the option options(ggsaveR.embed_data = FALSE)

title: Advanced Techniques with ggsaveR
text: Sometimes global options set need bypass single, specific ggsave() call. guard = TRUE argument serves “escape hatch,” telling ggsaveR step aside pass call directly original ggplot2::ggsave.

what: Use Case: Preventing Sensitive Data Embedding
title: Advanced Techniques with ggsaveR
text: Imagine ggsaveR.embed_data = TRUE set globally reproducibility. However, one specific plot generated sensitive large data want embed PNG file. guard = TRUE argument ensures one call, none ggsaveR enhancements applied. plot saved standard PNG, without embedded data, overwrite existing file name, regardless ggsaveR.overwrite_action setting. Warning: Using guard = TRUE script requires ggsaveR package loaded. , original ggplot2::ggsave throw “unused argument” error guard. advanced features make ggsaveR powerful tool managing complex data analysis workflows, enhancing reproducibility providing flexibility handle exceptions.
code: # Global setting for reproducibility options(ggsaveR.embed_data = TRUE)  # This plot contains sensitive information sensitive_data <- data.frame(   x = rnorm(10),   y = rnorm(10),   secret = "Confidential Information" ) p_sensitive <- ggplot(sensitive_data, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()  # Use guard = TRUE to save the plot without embedding the data # This call will use the standard ggplot2::ggsave behavior ggsave("sensitive_plot.png", p_sensitive, guard = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with ggsaveR
text: ggsaveR package designed supercharge ggplot2::ggsave() without requiring change existing code. vignette walk simplest, common use case: making ggsave() better single line code.

title: Getting Started with ggsaveR
text: Imagine analysis script saves several plots. want change plot saved—example, add PDF version publication—normally find modify every ggsave() call.
code: library(ggplot2)  # Create a plot p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, wt)) +   geom_point() +   labs(title = "Fuel Efficiency vs. Weight")  # Save the plot # In a real script, you might save this in a 'figures' directory # ggsave("figures/mpg_vs_wt.png", p)

title: Getting Started with ggsaveR
text: ggsaveR, can set global options control behavior subsequent ggsave() calls. First, load ggsaveR library. Now, let’s say want every plot saved PNG PDF. can set ggsaveR.formats option top script. Now, call ggsave(), automatically save formats. file extension filename argument used base name. simple setup allows enhance plot-saving operations existing project adding just two lines code top script. clean , can reset option NULL. vignette shown basic feature ggsaveR. vignettes series explore advanced capabilities.
code: library(ggsaveR) options(ggsaveR.formats = list(   list(device = "png", dpi = 300),   list(device = "pdf") )) # This single call will create both "mpg_vs_wt.png" and "mpg_vs_wt.pdf" ggsave("mpg_vs_wt.png", p) options(ggsaveR.formats = NULL)

title: Intermediate Usage of ggsaveR
text: vignette builds basics covered “Getting Started ggsaveR” explores advanced features, saving plots multiple dimensions preventing accidental file overwrites.
code: library(ggplot2) library(ggsaveR)  # Create a sample plot p <- ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length, color = Species)) +   geom_point() +   labs(title = "Sepal Length vs. Petal Length")

title: Intermediate Usage of ggsaveR
text: previous vignette, saw save plot multiple formats. ggsaveR.formats option highly flexible allows specify different dimensions, resolutions, parameters file. Let’s define set formats different purposes: high-resolution PNG presentation, PDF manuscript, SVG web use. Now, single ggsave() call generate three files respective specifications. original file extension ignored, filename used base name.
code: options(ggsaveR.formats = list(   # A high-res PNG for presentations   list(device = "png", width = 8, height = 5, units = "in", dpi = 300),   # A PDF for a manuscript, with dimensions in centimeters   list(device = "pdf", width = 18, height = 11, units = "cm"),   # An SVG for web/editing   list(device = "svg", width = 7, height = 4.5) )) # This creates "iris_plot.png", "iris_plot.pdf", and "iris_plot.svg" ggsave("outputs/iris_plot.png", p) # Reset the option options(ggsaveR.formats = NULL)

title: Intermediate Usage of ggsaveR
text: long analysis, might accidentally overwrite critical plot. ggsaveR provides ggsaveR.overwrite_action option control behavior. default "overwrite", mimics standard ggplot2::ggsave behavior.

title: Intermediate Usage of ggsaveR
text: Set option "stop" throw error file already exists. useful preventing accidental overwrites critical scripts.
code: options(ggsaveR.overwrite_action = "stop")  # This will work the first time ggsave("critical_plot.png", p)  # If you run it again, it will throw an error # ggsave("critical_plot.png", p) # Error: File 'critical_plot.png' already exists and ggsaveR.overwrite_action is set to 'stop'.

title: Intermediate Usage of ggsaveR
text: Alternatively, can set option "unique" automatically generate new filename intended one already exists. useful iterative analyses want keep versions plot. intermediate features provide much finer level control plots saved, helping streamline workflow protect work.
code: options(ggsaveR.overwrite_action = "unique")  # Run this once: creates "versioned_plot.png" ggsave("versioned_plot.png", p)  # Run this again: creates "versioned_plot-1.png" ggsave("versioned_plot.png", p)  # And again: creates "versioned_plot-2.png" ggsave("versioned_plot.png", p) # Reset to default options(ggsaveR.overwrite_action = "overwrite")

title: A Wrapper for ggplot2::ggsave with Extra Features
text: save every plot png pdf, just add two lines top script:
code: # --- my_analysis.R ---  library(ggplot2) library(ggsaveR) # 1. Load the library  # 2. Set your desired global options options(ggsaveR.formats = list(   list(device = "png", dpi = 300),   list(device = "pdf") ))  # ... lots of analysis code ... p1 <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, wt)) + geom_point() # NO CHANGE NEEDED HERE! This now saves mpg_vs_wt.png AND mpg_vs_wt.pdf ggsave("figures/mpg_vs_wt.png", p1, width = 7, height = 5)  # ... more analysis code ... p2 <- ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length)) + geom_point() # NO CHANGE NEEDED HERE! This now saves sepal_vs_petal.png AND sepal_vs_petal.pdf ggsave("figures/sepal_vs_petal.png", p2, width = 6, height = 6)

text: First, let’s load libraries create sample plot.
code: library(ggplot2) library(ggsaveR)  p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, wt, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   labs(title = "Fuel Efficiency vs. Weight")

title: A Wrapper for ggplot2::ggsave with Extra Features
text: Set ggsaveR.formats option list plot configurations. ggsaveR use filename argument base name create one file configuration.
code: options(ggsaveR.formats = list(   # A high-res PNG for presentations   list(device = "png", width = 8, height = 5, units = "in", dpi = 300),   # A PDF for a manuscript   list(device = "pdf", width = 18, height = 11, units = "cm"),   # An SVG for web/editing   list(device = "svg", width = 7, height = 4.5) ))  # This single call creates "outputs/my_plot.png", "outputs/my_plot.pdf", # and "outputs/my_plot.svg" with the specified dimensions. # The .png extension in the filename is ignored. ggsave("outputs/my_plot.png", p)  # Don't forget to reset the option when you're done! options(ggsaveR.formats = NULL)

title: A Wrapper for ggplot2::ggsave with Extra Features
text: Use ggsaveR.overwrite_action avoid losing work. can also set "stop" throw error file exists.
code: options(ggsaveR.overwrite_action = "unique")  # Run this once: creates "safe_plot.png" ggsave("safe_plot.png", p)  # Run this again: creates "safe_plot-1.png" instead of overwriting ggsave("safe_plot.png", p)  # Run this a third time: creates "safe_plot-2.png" ggsave("safe_plot.png", p)  # Reset to default options(ggsaveR.overwrite_action = "overwrite")

title: A Wrapper for ggplot2::ggsave with Extra Features
text: ggsaveR.embed_data = TRUE, ggsaveR automatically embed ggplot object, R code generated , session information directly PNG file.
code: options(ggsaveR.embed_data = TRUE)  # The plot object and call are captured and embedded in the file's metadata ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length)) +   geom_point(aes(color = Species)) |>   ggsave("plot_with_data.png")  # You can then retrieve this information later # embedded_info <- read_ggsaveR_data("plot_with_data.png")  # See the captured code # cat(embedded_info$plot_call) #> ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length)) + #>   geom_point(aes(color = Species))  # You can even replot the original object # embedded_info$plot_object  options(ggsaveR.embed_data = FALSE)

title: A Wrapper for ggplot2::ggsave with Extra Features
text: global options set need bypass one specific plot? Use guard = TRUE. tells ggsaveR step aside pass call directly ggplot2::ggsave. ⚠️ Warning: Using guard = TRUE script requires ggsaveR package loaded. ’s , original ggplot2::ggsave throw “unused argument” error.
code: # Let's set a global option to create unique filenames options(ggsaveR.overwrite_action = "unique")  # This call will create `final_figure.png`, then `final_figure-1.png`, etc. ggsave("final_figure.png", p)  # But for this one call, we want the standard ggplot2 behavior (overwrite) # The `guard` argument ensures ggsaveR's features are ignored for this call only. ggsave("final_figure.png", p, guard = TRUE)

title: A Wrapper for ggplot2::ggsave with Extra Features
text: ggsaveR.formats: list lists, inner list defines file save (e.g., list(device = "png", dpi = 300)). ggsaveR.overwrite_action: character string: "overwrite" (default), "unique", "stop". ggsaveR.embed_data: logical TRUE/FALSE (default FALSE). Controls data embedding PNGs. ggsaveR.creator: character string used “Author” file metadata (e.g., PDF properties).
